title: How Death Shapes Our Lives
content:
THROW LINE

Two roads diverged in a wood, and I—I took the one less traveled by. But why did everyone else choose the other road?

TENSION POINT

I need each one of you to close their eyes for a sec’, and to think of a moment; a moment where you decided to give in for the safe side instead of taking the risk, the road less traveled by? A moment where you decided to stay silent class, to keep secrets, to hide pain.

PERSPECTIVE

Okay. Now I think you must be wondering why I brought this up. I guess as we get deep into this you might wonder a little more before you finally realize it; just, hang on. So, because I trust you, guys, I want to tell you a story. . . about my life, more of a trivia honestly. Fair warning, it is not a happy trivia. I am a 16-year old teenager; however, I had many experiences with death. Don’t believe me? I first understood death 12 years ago when my grandfather, someone whom I was much connected to, died of cancer. At the time, he was probably everything to me, and understanding that people just go away for the young me was a bit too much. It was a pivotal change point in my life where I finally had time to think of how serious life is, define where I stand among the sentiments of death and life. Only that I never actually let it take over me the way it does to many. I had a couple more personal encounters with death, siblings, relatives, relatives of friends and even pets. For the sake of keeping this as friendly as possible, I will not get much into details. You must be thinking now, “what on earth is he talking about?” or more like “what death has to do with the roads?” and my favorite personally is “I did not get here to get sad.” More to that later.

I am here to tell why how the hideous five-letter lexicon that spells D-E-A-T-H not only destroys our chances in a good life but destroys us too, and how it is the reason why our social anxiety and fear is deep instilled within us. Before we go on, we need to agree on two things, one: death is inevitable and it does not make it any better to neglect it, and two: reconciling with how inexorable death is making a way better persona than evading it. Just one more thing before we hop on and understand why we should not fear death, let’s ask ourselves why we fear death. I asked myself that very question a couple of years ago and I found two significant parts for why death matters so much. Loath of loss, the fact that we despise parting with someone, and fear of the unbeknownst. Humans by nature are afraid of what they do not know and they have been that way ever since the first crack of dawn for them on Earth. Just like how until the disestablishmentarianism actually meant something that England considered a second look to their fear of science that deified what they saw as the divine laws of God.

When humans abandon their fear, they become more and more curious to learn feel, and once they do, they become more resilient with bad emotions like awe, panic, and sadness. One way to look it is how Vince Gilligan portrayed it in his show Breaking Bad. In Breaking Bad (don’t worry no spoilers ahead, seriously), our hero, Walter White has an exceptional yet underachiever temperament. He is constantly sticking to the conventional ways of doing things and not a bit a man of danger. One day, he receives news of his “insurmountable” to-come-soon death of lung cancer. Walter decides to run a methamphetamine drug operation that leads him into dangers he is absolutely certain he would not have stood a chance to before receiving his cancer news. He had nothing to lose, so why would not he anyways? I am not asking you to run a drug operation but just to realize how counterproductive death can be to us.

Does the way death undermine our lives has been going on forever, years, decades, centuries? No, millennia! Over 7 millennia on a record and more even before. Death has spawned what is currently estimated to be 4,200 religions that are loosely based on what is waiting for us after death, and where do our loved ones go. These religions have been built on the endless reassurance of the after-life safety to whoever decides to follow their particular religion. Death has got us to devote much time for building temples to worship mostly non-existing Gods (whether you currently a believer or not, we do agree that ancient Gods are sheer myths). Death has got us to fear science and all that seems supernatural for much longer than we could apprehend. Death has led us to destroy millions of books in The Alexandria Library and same for The House of Wisdom of Baghdad. Death made Empror Qin destroy half a millennium of scholar’s work, made the Muslims destroy The Bibliotheca of Nalada, and how the Japanese destroyed every single Chinese library during World War II. The death led us to slack back for years and we are the ones who are letting it do this, and we are still doing this right now, right here.

We are too afraid to face the music, and we get mad when someone like me rubs the truth in our faces! I keep repeating the word death because I know it hurts your ears to hear it; because you should not hate that word. The only thing it is doing to you is making you go from the magnificent person you are to someone much, much worse. That is why we choose the safer road because it is safer; it is as far as it could from death. At the same time, the livelihood of universe fades with each step along that road.

CONCLUSION AND CLOSURE

We are lost in these enfeeble woods; we get to see these diverged roads a lot; I think it is time to reconsider our priorities. Do you want to survive . . . or do you want to live? Just imagine how the world would be if we decide to keep our fear aside.
side:
* picture by Ahmed Adly on Unsplash

TED-Ed: How Death Shapes Our Lives, written originally as part of TED-Ed STEM Schools Club '19, is a TED Talk script written to discuss the idea of death in influencing human decision and how to overcome barrier created by fear, mentioning numerous examples of the results of the fear of death, ranging from mild to extremely destructive.

title: The Dilemma of Effort
content:
Tension Breaker

You are standing on a soccer pitch nearly 5 meters away from the goal at a steep angle. Today’s the last game of the UEFA Europe League and it’s only five minutes to go in the bout. Your team is down by one to win. This is the most intense moment of the whole season; the spectators are on the edge of their seats. Possibilities rush down your head. You start imagining scenarios in the couple seconds you have in hand but eventually, you have to kick the ball. You do that, and you lose. Do you know why?

Perspective 1: The Inner Game

What just happened down there is what W. Gallwey calls the inner game. Ever heard of that term? An inner game is basically the competition you play with yourself.

For years, people attributed athletic success to relentless training and hard work. While that is, indeed, true, another key element came into play. In his book An Inner Game of Tennis, Gallwey described the logical thinking of a player to be a fight between two parts of his mindset. His conscious thinking, Self I as Gallwey called it, would judge the actions of the acting subconscious mind, or Self II. His idea was that stopping conscious criticism of one’s action is the only way to earn success.

Gallwey believed that our conscious minds were incapable of performing tasks, but rather our subconscious thinking is what takes that responsibility. In his hypothesis, the only fair job our conscious mind can accomplish is to give ideas based on emotional perception. In other words, it would woe out of fear enough to push you down to what you fear.

You still remember that soccer field you were standing on a couple of minutes earlies? Good. We’re going to need that. Let’s slow things down a bit. The player had a few seconds to move a distance of a couple meters to catch the ball before his kick. He had the adrenaline rush of the last game of the season. By the time he got to the ball, the thoughts of losing were already deep down his system. His Self I already did the job of convincing him that it’s a no-no situation; he had no chance. Only if he did not think that way, he would have done it just like he did in his earlier training sessions where a loss was not even a risk.

Perspective 2: The Results Don’t Matter

Of course, when Timothy Gallwey wrote his book, he was focused on athletes. But if you look at it, his ideas were conclusive of much more. To understand, think back to a time where you would just think too much of an action you are positive you can do properly. And you do think of it a lot just because of your fear of the results. Not just sports, maybe a job interview; maybe a presentation; maybe even a date! Raise your hand if you can relate to that.

You did too many job interviews; this is your 20-something presentation or the third date in a year, whoah. But you still got the fear that it is not gonna work, even if it did like a hundred times before. It is funny isn’t it? Here, your mind is way too focused on the results, it would criticize your action, thinking that this pushes you further, when in fact it does the opposite.

Let me tell you a little story. Back in my sophomore year, we were just new to the high school environment as a whole. I was placed with a few kids in the same class. I was on parr with a few of the most skilled kids in the school. Some of us valued the effort, the others sought for the results. When our school reports came in, people who worked solely for the effort did significantly better than the other group. The trend appeared in both semesters and even the first semester of junior year. It could be seen in class, standardized tests, and extracurricular performance with varying degrees of disparity. Not because any of us were “better,” but rather the way we looked at things was different.

The trick here is that, as Brad Ledbetter described it in Building Your Inner Coach, most people fall into the pitfall of feeling the anxiety thinking about one of two things: the past… or the future. When you reflect that on Gallwey’s ideas, it starts to make more sense. The destructive experiences that are recalled during times of distress either come from retrospective experiences or future anticipations. It could be just the feeling of being of less value than someone else, or as in the cases of the player and the high school students, predicting the results of their actions.

From there, we can expand on the Gallwey’s perspective to include not only negative criticism but also positive thinking. To address the problem completely, positive thinking is just way too much-unneeded thinking. It is a distractive factor from the efficient effort itself, which is an added, wasteful effort. By quieting your judging side as a whole, by not thinking of what will or could have happened, by focusing only on the current effort, you can completely activate the subconscious powers of your mind.

One way to look it is how Vince Gilligan portrayed it in his show Breaking Bad. In Breaking Bad (spoilers ahead, seriously), our hero, Walter White has an exceptional yet underachiever temperament. He is constantly sticking to the conventional ways of doing things and not a bit a man of danger. One day, he receives news of his to-come-soon death of lung cancer. Walter decides to run a methamphetamine drug operation that leads him into dangers he is absolutely certain he would not have stood a chance to before receiving his cancer news. He had nothing to think of to criticize his action. He was a dead man walking, he had no future to think of whatsoever.

Perspective 3: Overdoeing is not doing, but it feels like it

But, here is a caveat. This approach altogether is faulty. Now, don’t get me wrong. I totally agree with the ideas presented by Gallwey and how we could expand it to tell us that we need to focus only on effort. So, why is it faulty? Gallwey stresses that it is all about the effort… but… effort is bad. Doing an effort is one of the most unhealthy practices humans get to pursue.

Let me try to put this into perspective. In a study by Kuroda Sachiko, a direct relationship between work hours and mental health risks was imposed. A few other studies followed to support the hypothesis. But… people who worked more hours showed more satisfaction despite the health risk! Surprising, isn’t it? I guess if you take a second to think of this, you might find yourself in a similar position, enjoying the things you're doing for the feel of self-redemption that comes from excessive effort.

Indeed, the effort shows a correlation with success, but it is not the best approach. One of the most prominent examples is Bethany Butzer, the Ph.D. graduate, Harvard Medical School employee, success-addict, who lived on anti-depressants for years to continue pursuing her targets. Again, showing how success does not necessarily mean well-being.

If we go back to Vince Gilligan’s Breaking Bad, and if you watch the show a bit further, you would see the failure of “just doing the effort”-approach. Walter White dies in pursuance of his methamphetamine empire, witnessing the death of his brother-in-law—when he did not need to take that risk at all. In the show, Walter started his operation to protect his family from financial instability following his death. In a two-year dilemma, Mr. White achieved his goal before half of the first year was over, risking everything with it.

But, why did he continue? He got consumed by the effort he did. He couldn’t abandon it, enough to risk it all. Now, watch this clip. “I did it for me. I liked it. I was good at it… I was alive.” That’s what he says, what he took two years to finally realize. For the most part, he tried to justify his wrongdoings as if he “did it for the family.” The way Vinca Gilligan represents the notion of self-consumption is brilliant on many levels. He expresses what “effort” could do to you.

If you were in a relationship with effort, it would be the toxic side. Effort consumes its doer by requiring more and more each time for the sake of it. It does not really care if the endeavor itself is productive or of worth, but it rather builds on the idea of demanding and seeking self-satisfaction.

We indulge ourselves in activities of hard work that is seldom helpful to regain self-confidence or to feel positive about the future. The problem is, it works… It works well enough that people don’t question the precision of their approach. Athletes who train harder usually gain more; students who study harder earn better grades; presenters who rehearse more often outperform those who rehearse less. It does bring success, sometimes. What it misses is… true happiness. The caffeine-like satisfaction of effort is temporary that you do more to feel its lingering tickles again and again.

Perspective 4: Overcoming the caveat and seeking patterns

If you have listened so far, then I need to ask you a question. Are you willing to solve this? Are you willing to change the way you look at things? Raise your hand if you do. The good news is… you definitely can.

Now, let me ask. Just out of curiosity. Ever been to the gym? How many of you did? The gym is nice, isn’t it? A good place to gain sheer confidence? I think so, too. If you have been there, had a coach or a trainer, you already know much of what I am going to say. Coaches would narrate the usual beginner mistakes they always do. Now, what are they? Remind me. Three things, to be exact: doing too much, using bad form, and thinking of perfection. They always tell you that science surpasses common sense and just because something makes sense doesn’t mean its true. Vigorous long-duration exercises just worn you out and make it harder to continue, jumping to heavier weights destroys progress, and thinking of perfection pushes you to do the two other mistakes.

It is quite astonishing how a gym coach would understand this while we still don’t believe in that in our classrooms or workplaces. The effort you do is never pulled off at the same quality, it naturally decays with time until you recharge. And recharging just gets harder each time, requiring more effort to perform simple tasks.

Thinking of the ways to execute your target actions with the least effort is the key element in doing the best quality effort. The question is: how will you do that? While it may seem like a difficult question at first, the answer is quite straightforward: thinking smart—seeking patterns, tracing mistakes, and exploiting the environment. I know. The answer sounds ambiguous, but bear with me.

If you know that a single task you do repeatedly, and trust me there are a lot, why can’t you invest time to think of a way to do it in an easier more effective way? You don’t need to study 12 hours per se when you can think of approaches that fit you to cut the down to 6, 4, or even 2. Since most of our days are utter repetitions of certain actions, seeking patterns is quite easy to utilize. To do that, you need to look out for patterns in not only your actions but rather your mistakes as well.

There’s a presentation, your 12th in only a few months. By now, you have already got most of the presenting idea. Rehearsing for extensive periods of time is uncanny, while not rehearsing at all is risky. The compromise? Trace your pitfalls one by one, keep an eye on them. Once you get to that 12th presentation, you already know that you always stand in an uncomfortable posture and crack your voice sometimes. This is your pattern. The mistake is repetitive that you need to rehearse just the mistake; you already know how to do the rest.

You took these mistakes, decided to ask for expert help on posture adjustment instead of wastefully trying by yourself; you got your advice from an online coach on an internet forum. For your voice, you started to adjust your tone, breath, and stops to make sure your voice is stable. Here, you captured the mistake, analyzed it, and saved yourself the effort of rehearsal hours that would end up needing less time overall to do more, not risking your mental health, and actually leading to bigger successes. You sought patterns in your performance; you identified repetitive behavior, and, finally, used the people around you to guide the process of adjustment.

Conclusion

Once you get the hang of this, you are good to go. You now know the secret formula to do anything in your life. The prodigious difference between work, hard work, and smart work.

You are still on standing on the soccer pitch at the UEFA Europe League final game. You approach the ball that you missed last time. The pitch is fired with heat rushing from everywhere. Your mind isolates you from the hefty awaiting silence of the stadium. Your heart gives a beat. You kick the ball, close your eyes, and time slows down. What is less than a second feels now like ages. You are awoken by the deafening cheering of the spectators. Your team holds you in the air. Your coach quickly tells you in a warm voice: “I am proud.” You did it.
side:
* picture by Kelly Sikkema on Unsplash

TEDxYouth@MaadiSTEM: The Dillema of Effort is a script written to discuss the idea of destructive thinking. The pieces builds up ideas from Thomas Gallawy The Inner Game and expands on his prespective, while introducing the problem of the self-redemption resulted from toxic effort and also offering a more inclusive and firm solution to the probelm.

The pieces builds up ideas from Thomas Gallawy The Inner Game and expands on his prespective, while introducing the problem of the self-redemption resulted from toxic effort and also offering a more inclusive and firm solution to the probelm.
